lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
*  A class which encapsulates the functionality Duke can do, current functionality is only the to-do list.
public class Actions { //actions that Duke can perform
} //end of while loop, means input is bye
*  A class which encapsulates the the deadline type of task
* String representation of a deadline object.
* @return The string representing the object with the state of the deadline task.
*  Main class that runs the Duke chatbot.
*  A class which encapsulates the exceptions that Duke throws
*  A class which encapsulates the empty description type of exception.
*  A class which encapsulates the event type of task.
* String representation of a event object.
* @return The string representing the object with the state of the event task.
*  A class which encapsulates the invalid command type of exception.
super("T_T what are you trying to do? I do not understand");
*  A class that handles parsing and processing of user inputs.
* A method for Duke to process the input given by the user.
* @param input The input string picked up by the scanner object.
* @throws EmptyDescriptionException If the input is a recognized command but no appropriate description after that.
* @throws InvalidCommandException If the input is an unrecognized command.
public void processInput(String input) throws EmptyDescriptionException, InvalidCommandException {
* A method to parse the user input and execute the appropriate action accordingly.
* @param input The user keyboard input after prompt from Duke.
Task currTask = currList.getTaskAt(Integer.parseInt(parts[1]) - 1); //the arraylist is 0 indexed, so task 1 is actually 0 index
System.out.println("Let's go! I've marked this task as done:");
Task unmarkTask = currList.getTaskAt(Integer.parseInt(parts[1]) - 1); //the arraylist is 0 indexed, so task 1 is actually 0 index
System.out.println("Oh man! I've marked this task as undone:");
case "deadline": //can abstract this whole case to be generalized
case "event": //can abstract this whole case to be generalized
case "todo": //can abstract this whole case to be generalized
System.out.println("Description cannot be empty, try again!");
*  A class that handles reading and writing and processing file contents.
private static final String home = System.getProperty("user.home");
private static final File file = new File(FILE_PATH);
* A method to read the file input into the task list.
* @param myReader The scanner that contains the file input
String dateEnglish = parts[1].substring(0, 11); //handle ) at the end
LocalDate inputDate = LocalDate.parse(dateEnglish, DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy"));
String dateEnglish = parts[1].substring(0, 11); //to handle the ) at the end
LocalDate inputDate = LocalDate.parse(dateEnglish, DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy"));
* A method to save tasks by writing them to a specified file.
* A method to create a file in the specified file path.
* A method to check if the file exists, and creates a file if it does not exist.
* @param taskList The file which contains the saved user tasks.
* A setter to change the task to be done.
* A setter to change the task to be undone.
* String representation of the current task.
* @return The task description and whether the task is done as a string.
*  A class which encapsulates the task list and operations on the list.
* Removes the specified task from the task list.
* @param remove The task to be removed.
* Adds a task to the end of the task list.
* @param t The task to be added.
* A method to find the length of the current task list.
* @return The length of the task list.
* A method to get the task at a specified index.
* @param index index we want to get our task
* @return the task retrieved at the index
*  A class which encapsulates the todo type of task.
* String representation of a todo object.
* @return The string representing the object with the state of the todo task.
*  A class which encapsulates the user interactions between Duke and the user.
* A method for Duke to tell the user how many tasks they currently have.
System.out.println("Now you have 1 task in the list.");
System.out.println("Now you have " + taskList.getLength() + " tasks in the list.");
* Greeting message when Duke is first executed.
System.out.println("Hello! I'm Duke, what's up today?");
* Error message when file is not found when trying to read from a file.
* Ending message after user terminates the program with "bye"
System.out.println("See ya! Come again~"); //end of bot
# create bin directory if it doesn't exist
# compile the code into the bin folder, terminates if error occurred
# run the program, feed commands from input.txt file and redirect the output to the ACTUAL.TXT
# compare the output to the expected output
